name: Scenario 1: Initial Traffic Spike Detection
description: In this scenario, you'll observe a sudden and dramatic increase in network traffic to your web server. Watch for indicators like rising connection rates, increasing CPU usage, and degrading server performance. Your goal is to quickly identify this as a potential DDoS attack and take immediate containment actions. You'll practice recognizing early warning signs before the attack fully overwhelms your infrastructure.

events.title: Unusual Traffic Spike Detected
events.description: Inbound TCP connection rate increased by 300% in the last 5 minutes

events.title: Connection Rate Limit Approaching
events.description: Firewall connection rate limit (20,000/min) at 76%. Many connections from same IP ranges.

events.title: Backend Server Health Degrading
events.description: One backend shows increased latency. Health check response time increased to 450ms.

events.title: Thread Pool Busy
events.description: Web worker threads are saturating under load.

events.title: High CPU Usage Alert
events.description: Server CPU usage reached 85%. Response times increasing.
You've detected a significant traffic spike with increasing CPU usage. What is your immediate response?

options.feedback: Correct! Quick containment reduces attack volume.
options.explanation: Blocking the heaviest sources immediately reduces impact.

options.feedback: Not ideal. Does not stop the attack.
options.explanation: Restarting causes downtime and the flood resumes.

options.text: Wait and monitor for 10 more minutes
options.explanation: Delaying allows further impact and service degradation.

options.text: Engage upstream provider for traffic scrubbing
options.feedback: Good choice, especially for large floods.
options.explanation: Upstream filtering removes malicious traffic earlier in the network path.
